snippet: The decision was made by the Food and Drug Administration after a wire that connects a defibrillator to a patient’s heart caused unintended shocks. St. Jude Medical stopped selling the wire in 2010.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration orders St Jude Medical to conduct more studies on patients implanted with heart-device components that were recalled in 2011 and that have been linked to as many as 20 deaths through unintended shocks; firm stopped selling its Riata lead wire in 2010.
lead_paragraph: The decision was made by the Food and Drug Administration after a wire that connects a defibrillator to a patient’s heart caused unintended shocks. St. Jude Medical stopped selling the wire in 2010.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Asks St. Jude for More Studies on Flawed Heart Device
headline.main: St. Jude Is Told to Study a Defect in Heart Devices
headline.print_headline: St. Jude Is Told to Study A Defect in Heart Devices
